Weeks 4‚Äì5 FAQs

FAQs
Posted

Wednesday July 12, 2023 at 7:58 PM

Hi everyone!

I just finished going through your past two problem sets and weekly check-ins and you‚Äôre doing great! And y‚Äôall did a fantastic job with Exam 1!

Here are a few common questions and comments from your weekly check-ins:

Am I just a dummy, or is this class a little challenging?

You are not a dummy! Economics is hard. It‚Äôs a completely different language for thinking about the world. The whole idea of using calculus to maximize your happiness when you‚Äôre constrained by a budget? That‚Äôs wild and not normal at all. Economists take the real world decisions made by individuals, firms, and countries and simplify them down to complex mathematical models. If you‚Äôve never been exposed to this stuff before, it‚Äôs completely foreign and bizarre and difficult.

This is hard stuff and everyone struggles. Do not worry!

This is also why I grade things in this class with the ‚úì system. In more official econ classes, like those offered in economics departments, you do calculus proofs in your problem sets and do all sorts of complex math where you‚Äôre graded really harshly. Some PhD programs in econ are actually designed to fail 50% of their students in the first semester (so cruel!)

I‚Äôm not a fan of that at all! My philosophy with the check system is that if you try to do a good job, great: ‚úì for you.

My goal in this class isn‚Äôt to make you economists and it isn‚Äôt to make sure you get every part of every question right. My goal is to make it so you can (1) talk like an economist know what you‚Äôre talking about and (2) understand how economics fits in with public policy. That‚Äôs all. If you know that people maximize utility where their preferences match their budget, that‚Äôs awesome; if you can‚Äôt remember what the first derivative of \(U = 0.667x^3 \sqrt{17y}\) is, after this semester, who cares.

What shapes indifference curves? Where do they come from?

Indifference curves are specific to individuals, and they‚Äôre shaped by tons of different factors, including location and experience (and marketing and advertising! This is why people get MBAs: to reshape individuals‚Äô indifference curves). They‚Äôre imaginary and hypothetical and live in your head, but they also reflect reality and are shaped by larger external processes.

Why do we need to differentiate between income and substitution effects?

It‚Äôs a way of thinking about behavior, and economists use them in real life to predict how people will respond to incentives or changes in income or prices. At their core, income and substitution effects help you see people‚Äôs preferences.

For instance, if someone is currently buying 1 gallon of milk a week and their income suddenly doubles, you might assume that they‚Äôll also double their consumption and start buying 2 gallons of milk a week. That would happen in a world with no substitution effects‚Äîthey‚Äôd double their consumption because their income is doubled. But that‚Äôs often not the case. This person might start buying a little bit more milk a week because they‚Äôre richer (income effect), but they‚Äôll likely spend that doubled income on other things (substitution effect)

This matters for policies that provide people with benefits or that cut people‚Äôs taxes (since both of those things effectively change people‚Äôs incomes). For example, if a state government removes its gas tax, people in theory become richer and can spend that money elsewhere. To make math easier, let‚Äôs pretend that a state government cuts all gas prices in half. Naively, you might assume that a change like that would make it so people drive twice as much, since their gas budget just doubled. But in reality, that‚Äôs not the case‚Äîthere might be some more driving (income effect), but that new extra money is going to go to other things (food, rent, etc.)

My income and substitution effects were all different!

Yep! That‚Äôs fine. Because indifference curves are all imaginary, all that matters for this class is the mechanics of decomposing a total effect into income and substitution effects. You likely got different effects from what was in the answer key, and that‚Äôs okay.

Why are nonprofits treated differently from private firms?

There‚Äôs a whole host of reasons for this. Nonprofits don‚Äôt have owners. Any profits a nonprofit generates have to go back into the organization itself‚Äîyou can‚Äôt buy stocks in the Red Cross or Amnesty International. This is because governments and the nonprofit sector have a centuries-long arrangement where nonprofits help provide public goods and charitable work in exchange for not having to pay taxes (but also not having owners like a regular firm)

Question 6 in problem set 3 / Question 1 in problem set 4 was rough

Yeah, sorry, utility maximization is admittedly hard stuff. There are a few core mathematical principles for microeconomics, and budget lines and indifference curves are one of them. Ultimately, a population‚Äôs aggregated indifference curves, even though they‚Äôre fake, generate a supply function, which is real (ü§Ø). Plus the mechanics of optimizing your consumption to maximize your happiness under constraints is something humans do (and you might start doing it more explicitly now, thinking about budget lines and indifference curves when you‚Äôre deciding which groceries to buy). Again, it‚Äôs hard stuff. But you can learn it!

Question 5 in problem set 5 was so so hard.

Yep, that‚Äôs the trickiest, most complicated problem set question of the semester (sorry!), but it‚Äôs also one of the most realistic. It‚Äôs the closest you‚Äôll get to doing actual real-world economic analysis in this class. This is the kind of stuff that companies and nonprofits and governments actually really do. Large companies like Google, Amazon, GM, Kroger, etc. all have chief economists, which seems weird! That seems more like a government position, like an employee at the Fed. But these companies and their economics teams use the principles of microeconomics to estimate supply curves using experiments and regression equations, and then work to find the optimal price to set for their products given the competition in the market and their company‚Äôs market power. They do everything you did in that question (and more).

Sometimes it‚Äôs unclear which thing should go on which axis

Yeah, like in question 3 on problem set 4, I didn‚Äôt specify if clothing or food should go on the x- or y-axis. That‚Äôs because it ultimately doesn‚Äôt matter. Put them wherever.

In the answer key, clothing was on the x-axis, but that‚Äôs just because I put it there. It‚Äôd work just the same if food was on the x-axis (the graph would just look a little different and the notch would be along the y-axis instead of the y-axis). Though it‚Äôs often easiest to put the thing that changes on the x-axis, similar to stats graphs. In statistics we put the dependent variable (or the outcome, or the thing that responds to changes) on the y-axis and the independent variable (or the treatment, or the explanatory variable, or the thing that we change) on the x-axis.

How can we remember the difference between changes in supply/demand and changes in quantity supplied/demanded?

This is one of the more trickier and subtler points in microeconomics, and it trips me up all the time too. This short little video is helpful (they have a bunch of other really neat short videos too)

Why do we get different prices when using the marginal revenue and the demand curve formula?

In question 5 from problem set 5, you found the ideal profit-maximizing quantity, but when you try to find the corresponding price for that quantity, you get two different numbers. This is normal and a result of a monopoly situation, so don‚Äôt worry! Following the MR formula, the theater should only charge $25ish, since they‚Äôre not producing as much as the socially optimal level. But, society is willing to pay a higher price for this reduced quantity! If you keep going up from the profit maximizing price and quantity on the marginal revenue point and go up to the demand curve, you‚Äôll see that people would be willing to pay $41 for tickets. So in an effort to maximize profits, the theater should only sell 180 tickets. They should charge $25 for each, but people would pay up to $41, so they‚Äôll charge the higher price because why not? It‚Äôs free money for the theater! There will thus be fewer, more expensive tickets than you‚Äôd see under regular competition
